data.title: Added color themes to the text editor
data.body:
Adds themes for the code / text editor.

Firstly, i'm unsure if this is the best / godot way of going about this, so feel free to not merge.

With that said It creates a new folder called `text_editor_themes` under the .godot setting directory, that themes can be dropped in too. Theme files end in `.tet` for text editor theme. The layout of a `.tet` file follows the following format:

`color_name : html color code`

Themes are then selected via the editor setting with a drop down, the name of the theme is the same name as the file. The theme files are only read when changing themes via the drop down in the editor settings, or reloading themes via `file -> reload theme` inside the text editor.

The only real enforcement is a theme cannot be called `default` and themes must be placed inside of the  `text_editor_themes` directory.

closes #1656

data.title: x11: Flush the X output buffer after changing mouse mode
data.body:
Ensures the event is received before a break happens.

Fixes #2232

data.title: Change particles to use emission rate rather than max allowed particles.
data.body:
**Issue description:** (what happened, and what was expected):

Currently, particle emitters don't have an emission rate property, they just have an "Amount", which controls the maximum particles allowed to exist at one time (from that emitter). You can't directly control the particle emission rate. Besides being confusing, this causes at least two issues:

**1. Changing the particle Lifetime changes the emission rate** (double the lifetime --> half the emission rate), which means you have to adjust two properties at once to get the effect you want. 

**2. Animating the Amount to a lower value will delete particles instantly rather than letting them expire normally.** This is the real issue. Because of this there's no way to animate an emitter's spawn rate without it looking horrible and choppy as random particles vanish instantly. Enabling/disabling works fine, but obviously that's pretty limited.  

[Edit] **3. Since Amount and Lifetime are linked, we can never have a random particle lifetime feature.** Being able to spawn particles with variable lifetimes would be a nice addition to particle systems, but since that would mess up your spawn rate, it's not really an option with the current setup. 

_A side issue: the Amount can't be set to zero for some reason._

data.title: Mesh class needs to be un-crippled
data.body:
For a long time the Godot supports accessing  mesh internals only using GLES calls,
and it is basically disabled in many configurations. While geometry is there, Godot can't access it.
which is really not justifiable. So Mesh surfaces access method should be implemented
without using GLES where this path is not supported.
Access to geometry data is really useful for various mesh processing and preparing
internal assets, like collision helpers.

data.title: godot should un-lock mouse in case of being stopped due to error
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**
Any (Linux)

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
The damn cursor stays locked and unusable if execution is stopped because of errors,
which is really damn annoying

**Steps to reproduce:**
Use mouse locking in your code, do some bad code (to be executed later than that),
have fun.

data.title: Made trackpad behaviour optional in 3D mode (issue #4265)
data.body: Added an option in editor settings as a boolean "3d_editor/trackpad_hint". It is disabled by default.

data.title: Tilemap needs a NavigationPolygonInstance culling feature
data.body:
**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Tilemap seems to be well optimized as it splits up the tiles into quadrants, so I can make a 1k tiles x 1k tiles Tilemap with no noticeable performance loss. However the optimization only seems to apply to Sprites (and maybe StaticBody2D nodes, I'm not sure). So my issue is that some of my tiles have attached NavigationPolygonInstance nodes, which don't seem be culled. So right now, generating paths for worlds of 300x300 and larger causes significant performance drops, even for short distance path finding. So now I need to make my own system to add/remove those tiles as the player moves around.

However I see this feature not being desirable for some games that want long distance navigation paths, so maybe a "Enable Navigation Culling" checkbox could be implemented for those of us that do want it.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
I can upload my game to demonstrate the issue if requested.

data.title: Fixed #4163 (intersect_shape crashes on results limit)
data.body: max_result was not used in the function, producing out-of-bound array access when collisions count exceeds the limit.

data.title: AnimationTreePlayer: allow animating resource properties.
data.body: e.g. Particles2D config and param values.

data.title: AnimationTreePlayer: constructor now sets processing mode.
data.body: This doesn't affect issue #4271, but it _has_ to be a bug: the constructor was creating and setting a local variable and neglecting to set the object property with the same name.

data.title: Resolving of absolute paths with leading res:// and without result in different final paths
data.body:
**Operating system or device:**

Windows 10 64 bit, in the editor.

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):

```
const MyScript = preload("res://path/to/MyScript.gd")
const MyScript2 = preload("/path/to/MyScript.gd")

# later

print(MyScript.get_path())
print(MyScript2.get_path())
print(MyScript == MyScript2)
```

Expected output:

```
res://path/to/MyScript.gd
res://path/to/MyScript.gd
True
```

Actual output:

```
res://path/to/MyScript.gd
res:///path/to/MyScript.gd
False
```

data.title: Don't hardcode res://addons/ path
data.body:
**Problem:**

Currently, addons path is hardcoded to point to `res://addons/*` [as evidenced by code](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/blob/a895e2e372c9df2a9972f38134ae0ea9c8bf45a8/tools/editor/editor_plugin_settings.cpp#L22).

Before addons were introduced, the only hardcoded paths were `res://engine.cfg`, `res://export.cfg` and `res://override.cfg`, all of which are `.cfg` files (I might be missing some of them though, that is based on a quick code search). In other words, even though we configure all paths in `engine.cfg` and `export.cfg`, addons are all folders in a hardcoded folder, without `.cfg` files for listing them, and/or allowing them to go in other directories (E.g. "What if I want them to go in `res://vendor/plugins/`?").

**Proposed solutions:**
1. Allow the `res://addons/` path to be changed in `engine.cfg`.
   - **Pros:** Would allow for a bit more freedom when choosing a project structure. (E.g., I can move all addons under the `sahder/addons` folder instead.)
   - **Cons:** The auto-installer/addon lib just got a bit more complex...
2. Add a `[addons]` section to `engine.cfg`, where addons are listed as paths to their respective `plugin.cfg` or folder.
   - **Pros:** Would allow some addons to be enabled and others disabled, without moving the folders around.
   - **Cons:** Harder to manually add an addon, maybe an installer GUI would be necessary.
3. Add a `addons.cfg` file, which contains that section instead of `engine.cfg`
   - **Pros:** Better division of concern, `engine.cfg` is less bloated.
   - **Cons:** One more hardcoded path, `engine.cfg` isn't that big yet.

Note that if 2 or 3 is chosen, it might be nice to include the link/git repo from which the addon was downloaded, so we would be able to distribute the project without the addons inside. (Or.... git submodules to the rescue `;)`)

data.title: Both "Scene/Save Scene As.." and "File/Save All" use Shift-Ctrl-S
data.body:
Found on Windows 10, Godot v2.0.2.

When pressing Shift-Ctrl-S while editing a script, I expected all unsaved scripts to be saved. Instead I saw the Scene/Save As dialog. I'd like the same behaviour as File/Save All, or at least some way to distinguish between the two. I see the File/Save All as being used more often than Scene/Save As, and so should have 'priority' (i.e. I'd like to see it retain the Shift-Ctrl-S rather than some other combination).

Edit any script. Type Shift-Ctrl-S. The Scene/Save As dialog appears.

data.title: Suggestions for the Plugin API
data.body:
Important plugins, `SpatialEditorPlugin`, `CanvasItemPlugin`, `TileMapEditorPlugin`, or simply every C++ editors, should have its own API for extension. Based on #4174, various plugins can work together like one, but a big problem with this now is the plugins dont know exactly what the others are doing.
For example creating a addon for filtering(Random tiles or auto-mapping, #843) tiles in a `TileMap` node is not possible, or not practical, you can handle the input but you don't know what tool the editor is using.

---

I created a small example for the `TileMapEditorPlugin`:  
- TileMapEditorPlugin
  - RandomTileAddon
  - PolygonDrawAddon
  - MinimapAddon

In this case we have three different plugins with different functionalities. They need differents API functions, and different levels of access.

| Name | Description | Required API |
| :-: | --- | --- |
| RandomTileAddon | Simple addon to draw random tiles automatically | The `TileMap` editor have the `_set_cell` function used by all tools of the editor, for this addon it is interesting to override the function when the user press a key or toggle a button |
| PolygonDrawAddon | Addon for drawing a "polygon" of tiles | This addon will use two existing features line drawing and bucket fill. If the user "activate" the addon all the viewport input will be handled by this addon, and the addon will release the "focus" when the polygon is finished. A virtual function for drawing on the editor viewport, for example `viewport_draw`, can be useful for this addon |
| MinimapEditorAddon | Simple addon to display a minimap of the `TileMap`, for faster navigation | This is a especial type of addon it don't need override any function, handle any viewport input or draw anything on the viewport. It will only need access to the viewport(#3992) to add a custom widget, which will handle all the input and drawing |

---

Other ideas:
- A addon for a editing a custom type can have a "special access", it can override some functions of the C++ plugin, or simply "override" the entire plugin.
- A similar API of the `SpatialEditorGizmo` for 2D can make addons for this type of node faster and simpler.
- Every plugin should have a simple API for extending it's toolbar menu, panels or docks.

data.title: Update OpenSSL to version 1.0.1s
data.body:
To close #2780.
Compiled for platforms x11, windows and android on ubuntu 14.04 but only tested by this example:
http://docs.godotengine.org/en/latest/tutorials/http_client_class.html
on ubuntu by this cert file: `/etc/ssl/certs/ca-certificates.crt`

data.title: Fixes 64 bit MSVC builds, disables bits parameter
data.body:
Also Enables automatic detection of architecture for the MSVC compilers.
Builds without assembly optimisations for x64
Closes issue #3098

Info: Currently godot cannot be compiled out of the box for 64 bit on MSVC compiler, because until this fix we were not properly seting up the MSVC compiler to compile for different architectures... 

In fact, setting arhitecture in MSVC is somewhat impossible for scons (a wee bit hard manually, and shoudn't be done, because it would clash with attempts of the developer to set it up for the arhitecture he wants to build for...)

So, in light of that, this fix disables the bits parameter in scons for MSVC, but it also enables detection of the compiler and configures scons bits automatically instead (ie based on which dev prompt the user has invoked, or which vcvarsall.bat setting it has invoked...).

I hope the instructions that scons gives on errors are sufficient to allow you to manage to test properly. I tested on MSVS 2015 Community Eddition (cl.exe version 18) prompts and vcvarsall.bat, but this should support a wide range of MSVC versions. Needs testing, of course.

This pull changes how MSVC build parameters work so Travis test should fail if it is setup to test MSVC builds (seems it's not setup).

Best regards.

P.S. sys.exit() used because i saw it used in SConstruct
P.P.S. Please let me know if i need to rebase this properly.

data.title: Port collision and layer masks to 3D
data.body:
Fixes #1759.
I added `type_mask` and `layer_mask` to Raycast nodes,  `collision_mask` and `layer_mask` to Area nodes, and `collision_mask` to PhysicsBody nodes.

I have tested the code, but I'm not sure if I've copied everything from 2D correctly, so it would be nice if you test it too :smile: (though I can just make another PR with missing content).

data.title: Tooltip ignores parent scaling
data.body:
Godot 2.0.1-stable Win10 64bit

Tooltip's position is invalid if Controls are scaled
(a similar problem happens if you set a custom drag control)

**Steps to reproduce:**
1. Create a new scene, add a main Control element
2. Create a Panel, change it's scale to 2,2
3. Create a Button as the Panel's child, set some text and tooltip text
4. Start the scene
5. Hover over the button

When you hover over the button the tooltip will be misplaced. You will not see the tooltip at all if the button is far from 0,0 (top left of the screen).
This may be related to Control.set_drag_previev() also messing up the position if there is a scale involved.

data.title: AnimationTreePlayer's default value for Process Mode is null?
data.body:
on Godot 2.0.1_stable

Is AnimationTreePlayer supposed to have a default value for Process Mode?

I know this is really trivial but it actually caused me a lot of trouble when I replaced AnimationTreePlayer with AnimationPlayer and couldn't figure out why it wouldn't play any animations. Turns out it inherited the null Process Mode value from the AnimationTreePlayer it replaced.

data.title: 'Breaked' signal call fix.
data.body: 'Breaked' signal call arguments now cast to variant to prevent invalid arguments errors being printed.

data.title: Subclasses can now extend from other subclasses in relative scripts.
data.body: This allows you to define a subclass in one script file, and then extend it directly from a class or subclass from another file while using a relative path. Originally, you could only do this with an absoloute path.

data.title: Fixed undo redo interaction with find replace
data.body: Fixed find and replace creating multiple undo / redo steps.

data.title: Godot should not include insecure OpenSSL code in its source tree
data.body:
openssl had several important security bugfixes in the last years.
embedding third-party code in a source tree is equivalent to a fork, so there need to be sufficient resources to maintain it.
in security-critical software this either means continuous updates or backported patches.
if these resources are not available, it's better to use the system supplied version.
just to make it easy to build for windows folks doesn't mean godot needs to be insecure.

removing the code would also fix the issue that github mistakenly classifies godot as a C project, while in reality it's C++.
( https://github.com/godotengine/godot/search?l=c )
